user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun(osal_id_t timebase_id, uint32 *freerun_val)
{
    int32                          return_code;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(freerun_val);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, timebase_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, token);

        *freerun_val = timebase->freerun_time;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) in the provided target function or the related definitions. The target function only performs a pointer null-check (OS_CHECK_POINTER), calls OS_ObjectIdGetById to obtain a token/index, and reads a uint32 field (timebase->freerun_time) from the timebase table. None of these operations invoke any string handling functions or perform string buffer manipulations that could lead to out-of-bounds string accesses.

The only string-like object present is the timebase_name array inside OS_timebase_internal_record_t, but no code in the provided snippets reads from or writes to that array using the standard string functions. Therefore, based on the supplied code, there are no fragments that need investigation under Rule 21.17. If string functions are used elsewhere in the project (other translation units), those usages should be reviewed; they are not present in the supplied code.
